definitions.definition: to stop; to make somebody/something stop

examples.text: She walked towards him and then halted.
‘Halt!’ the Major ordered *(= used as a command to soldiers)*.
The police were halting traffic on the parade route.
The trial was halted after the first week.
A sudden shout made them halt in their tracks and look around.
All these ideas for expansion were abruptly halted by the outbreak of war.
The strike effectively halted production at the factory.
We are failing to halt the destruction of the rainforest.
She criticized his failure to halt the slide in the government's unpopularity.

definitions.definition: to suddenly make somebody stop by frightening or surprising them; to suddenly stop because something has frightened or surprised you

examples.text: The question stopped Alice in her tracks.
Suddenly he stopped dead in his tracks: what was he doing?
The disease was stopped in its tracks by immunization programmes.

wordOrigin: late 16th cent.: originally in the phrase make halt, from German haltmachen, from halten ‘to hold’.
